Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Assay Optimization for Highly Sensitive Detection of Human Cardiac Troponin I

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposal seeks to develop and optimize a novel approach for detection of a blood borne marker (Troponin I) associated with cardiovascular disease. This biomarker has been shown to have predictive value in diagnosis of myocardial infarctions. Therefore, it is important to monitor such biomarker rapidly and onsite - either in the first responder vehicle or in the emergency room. This proposal addresses the need for rapid detection of troponin by simplifying traditional sandwich immunoassay/ELISA used for analysis of this biomarker. This simplified assay will use just one antibody/one step for detection of troponin and will involve a novel mutant antibody oriented on the surfaces of the biosensor in a controlled manner. Troponin binding to this to this fluorescently labeled antibody will result in the change of fluorescence intensity. Successful completion of this project may lead to future development of biosensor for rapid, point of care diagnosis of myocardial infarctions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to develop and optimize a novel approach for detection of human cardiac troponin I (cTnI), a blood borne biomarker associated with cardiovascular disease. Recent research and clinic studies have shown that this biomarker has predictive value in diagnosis of myocardial infarctions (MI). Unfortunately, the early symptom may allow a developing myocardial infarction to go unnoticed and have deleterious effects on patients. It is now known that measurable cTnI levels only appear in the bloodstream 3-6 h after the cessation of regional coronary blood flow, e.g. initiation of the MI process. For the clinic diagnosis of patients with chest pain, it is important to detect and monitor such biomarker rapidly and onsite - either in the first responder vehicle or in the emergency room. The present study seeked to address the need for rapid detection of cTnI by novel fluorescence sensors, electrochemical sensors and surface plasmon resonance sensors with higher sensitivity and selectivity.

The novel fluorescence sensor simplified traditional enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) by using just one antibody/one step for detection of cTnI, and it involved a novel mutant antibody oriented on the surfaces of the biosensor in a controlled manner. One expected that once cTnI bound to the fluorescently labeled antibody, it would result in the change of fluorescence intensity. By monitoring the fluorescence changes, one would be able to detect the concentration of cTnI. However, the experiments showed that the dye moiety (i.e. fluorescein isothiocyanate, FITC) was released from the quartz slide before the detection of the target molecule cTnI. The exact cause of this release is unknown, although the surface silanization steps have been repeated many times successfully with consistent results. The anti cTnI IgG binding to the quartz slide was also successful. We hypothesize that due to the high sensitivity of FITC to light, a photo induced cleavage may be the explanation. In order to determine whether the linker molecules affect the release of FITC, additional control experiments were performed on the thiol modified quartz slide. Based on the experimental data, similar background enhancement was clearly seen. Further investigation provided additional evidence that a release of fluorophore was occurring over time leading to an increase of the photoluminescence emission. Similar background enhancement was also found when utilizing other proprietary fluorophores, indicating that the dye moiety was still found to be released from the slide into solution as well.

Since we currently cannot find out how to fix fluorophores without releasing in the backgound, we explored other strategies without attaching fluorophores using electrochemical sensors and surface plasmon resonance sensors. Beside the advantage of labeling free, electrochemical immunosensors and surface plasmon resonance sensors have other intrinsic advantages, such as simple pretreatment procedures, precise measurements, fast analytical time, excellent limit of detection, and miniaturized instrumentation. Both methods are expected to be able to detect subnanogram per milliliter or even below pictogram per milliliter levels of cardiac troponin I. We are right now in the process of optimizing the experimental conditions to improve the sensitivity and selectivity using these sensors. We are positive that these sensors will actually function well with lower detection limit and higher sensitivity. We will update and report the results once we obtain the complete data.
